title.narrative: DECP COVID-19 support to ZFE Zambia in 2020
D2D - Akvo Software Tools

description.narrative: A1 To continuously maintain and improve Flow so it can be used to monitor infrastructure and WASH services B1 To continue to improve Caddisfly by adding new water quality parameters. B2 To roll out smarthphone based water quality monitoring in Africa and Asia. B3 To enable data exchange with several external sensors for water, soil and air quality. C1 To continue to improve Lumen by adding new features C2 To use Lumen to support governments in managing water and sanitation services and infrastructure at national scale. D1 To continuously maintain and improve RSR D2 To continue to support our existing RSR users to share information online. E1 To continuously maintain and improve Akvopedia E2 To include a database of WASH surveys, ideally including a standardized survey library for WASH SDG monitoring (in cooperation with WHO).

The D2D Akvo Software tools is one of the 9 child-projects of the Akvo Data to Decision project.
Akvo is promoting a sustainable, collaborative approach to solving development issues. We work hard to ensure our systems are being maintained, continuously improved and become well supported and embedded within partner organisations, leading to greater long-term benefits and high levels of sustainability. Over recent years, we have further improved existing and developed new open source tools that we will use in this program to support partners and national governments, to monitor and provide WASH services sustainably at scale.
Continuous maintenance and development of software is costly, and by sharing investment and improvements openly amongst our global partner network, we are able to sustainably provide services to our partners for a low fee. We believe this is vital, because our partners depend on this infrastructure and should be confident that the long-term investments to maintain and continuously improve the systems are secured.
Within the D2D Akvo Software tools project, we will focus on further developing and professionalising our set of tools, consisting of: * Akvo Flow * Akvo Caddisfly * Akvo Lumen * Akvo RSR * Akvopedia With a specific focus on ensuring we connect our tools best to our partners and build capacity to make best use of the tools.

title.narrative: Yangon Port Development

description.narrative: Based on the congestion/limitations of the old city port and the existing Thilawa port and taken into account the growing transport needs to cater for domestic purposes and trade to West China, it is expected that the city ports and the actual Yangon river navigation capacity will reach its limits by 2027-2030 (depending on COVID-19 recovery). The Yangon Region Government (YRG) therefore intends to develop new port facilities towards the sea on the West Bank of the Yangon River. These new facilities are designated as a location to which the existing Yangon city ports are to be relocated (strategic objective), but will also provide necessary capacity and cost reduction on the short-term (as inner ports will be relocated gradually). By shifting the inner ports, the vessel turnaround time will be reduced as the port would be closer to the sea and the dredging expenses spending on inner shallow areas will be saved too. The map below provides an overview of the port locations in Yangon, indicating the two current port locations (City Port Area and Thilawa Port) and the intended relocation of the City Port Area (New West Bank Port).

title.narrative: WASH Officer UNHCR Cameroon (DSS220CM01)

description.narrative: WASH Officer UNHCR Cameroon – Supporting the provision of WASG services to persons of concern to UNHCR. This includes ensuring that an adequate level of water service is provided at each site in accordance with applicable UNHCR and National Standard and in line with addressing the global Covid-19 pillars of activities in regard to (1) risk communication and community engagement – WASH awareness and hygiene promotion, (2) infection prevention and control – access to adequate WASH services to institutions and households, (3) operational support and logistics – ensure enough contingency stocks according to standards.

WASH Specialist Kyrgyzstan

description.narrative: Under the general guidance of the UNICEF Chief of Field Office and in close cooperation with the Climate Change Officer, Education Specialist, Health and Nutrition Officer, the Emergency WASH Specialist will support the assessment of WASH needs in Education and Healthcare Institutions, analyze the collected data, present the findings and prepare a costed action plan with broad range of WASH interventions, defining also UNICEF’s country emergency response to COVID-19 in this area, in line with UNICEF’s Core Commitments for Children (CCCs). Planned interventions must consider the inclusiveness of people with disabilities and gender.

Duration of mission (in number of days)
WASH Cluster Coordinator South Sudan UNICEF

description.narrative: Under the guidance and supervision of the Chief WASH section, the WASH Specialist supports the development, preparation, management, implementation, monitoring and evaluation UNICEF WASH programme within the current COVID-19 Response. The COVID-19 WASH Specialist provides technical guidance and management support throughout the programming processes, to facilitate the administration and achievement of the WASH IPC-related output results in the country programme. The COVID-19 WASH Specialist will work closely with IPC WASH Co Lead to ensure that all agreed standards, SOPs, and other technical guidance are well captured in UNICEF programming. The consultant will assist and fill in whenever requested by IPC Co Lead.The COVID-19 WASH Specialist is accountable for the quality of UNICEF interventions as regard to WASH IPC in healthcare facilities and communities.

description.narrative: The Associate WASH Officer Uganda UNHCR provides remote support to the UNHCR Country Operation, in coordination with the Government and UNHCR Partners, to coordinate the provision of WASH services to persons of concern to UNHCR. This support will include the collation, analysis, and reporting of WASH data, as well as support to the COVID-19 response.

WASH Specialist South Africa UNICEF

description.narrative: The WASH Specialist UNICEF South Africa is responsible for / supports the development, planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of UNICEF’s emergency response in activities and results related to safeguard and improve public health of the affected population by promoting safe hygiene practices addressing behavioural aspects and ensuring they have access to appropriate means to practice them effectively; ensuring overall efficiency, effectiveness and delivery of results in accordance with UNICEF’s Core Commitment for Children in Emergencies (CCCs) and national and international humanitarian standards. This includes the response to COVID-19.

MHPSS Consultant Albania WHO

description.narrative: The MHPSS consultant in Albania, working for WHO, will have the responsibility for coordination MHPSS operations to ensure the timely delivery, effective and efficient implementation of the activities, to achieve the best attainable health status for the populations that are affected by both the earthquake and COVID-19.

title.narrative: MHPSS Specialist Lebanon UNICEF

description.narrative: On 4th of August 2020, two explosions hit the city of Beirut, which killed more than 200 people and injured over 4000 people. Lebanon had already been suffering from political instability, economic collapse and a surge in COVID-19 cases. These multi-faceted disasters have a devastating and profound impact on the lives and wellbeing of the population and there is therefore an urgent need for reinforced capacity and resources to enable coordinated multi-sectoral MHPSS response to the varying and complex mental health and psychosocial needs of children, adolescents and families.

title.narrative: MHPSS Consultant Peru WHO

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Consultant in Peru for WHO will be to work with technical UN programmes, PAHO Country Offices and Ministers of Health in prioritized countries in the region, to achieve the best attainable health status for the populations that are affected by COVID-19. The following countries have been mapped as priority for this project: Peru, Haïti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Guatemala, Bolivia and Ecuador.

title.narrative: MHPSS Expert Pakistan WHO

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Consultant in Pakistan for WHO is to support the Technical Working Group on MHPSS and specifically with the coordination with ministries, INGOs and NGOs. The consultant will have the overall responsibility for coordinating operations to ensure the timely delivery, effective and efficient implementation of the activities, to achieve the best attainable mental health and psychosocial well-being status for the populations that are affected by COVID-19

title.narrative: MHPSS Officer COVID-19 Interagency TWGs in the African Region

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Officer COVID-19 Interagency TWGs in the African Region will be to provide technical support to francophone countries in Africa to strengthen the coordination of the MHPSS response and supporting the interagency MHPSS Technical Working Groups.

title.narrative: MHPSS specialist COVID emergency Haiti (WHO/PAHO)

description.narrative: As part of the WHO/PAHO Regional project to support countries to strengthen and scale up their MHPSS response capacity, the MHPSS Capacity Building Expert for Haiti will support the two Mental Health coordinators nominated by the Ministry of Health of Haiti to establish a MHPSS coordination mechanism.This project has the following objectives:Objective 1: Strengthen national capacities to coordinate and provide quality MHPSS to communities affected by the COVID-19 pandemicObjective 2: Develop and adapt communication materials related to MHPSSObjective 3: Strengthen the capacity of health professionals, frontline workers, health managers and decision makers to deliver effective MHPSS responses to the COVID-19 pandemic within and beyond the health systemPAHO will seek partnerships on both operational and technical levels with national and international non-governmental organizations, WHO/PAHO collaborating centers, academia and the Red Cross in order to enhance the Project’s impact on populations.

title.narrative: MHPSS Technical Working Group Coordinator Azerbaijan

description.narrative: Mental Health & Psycho-Social Support (MHPSS) has been identified as a priority need for the population of Nagorno-Karabakh.The leaders of Armenia, Azerbaijan and Russia signed a trilateral statement on a cessation of hostilities. This coupled with the spike in COVID-19 infections and deaths, has rendered many amongst affected population vulnerable to mental health and psychosocial distress.There is a need to have a coordinated approach on MHPSS activities in the country with focus on technical aspects including mapping of partners, capacity building, monitoring and evaluation and capacity building for long term institution of MHPSS services in regular services.To ensure responsibility, accountability and productivity of all MHPSS actors, it was agreed that a technical forum for MHPSS actions is necessary to bringing together the MHPSS actors functioning under the established and agreed Working Group. To facilitate this, the establishment of a MHPSS Technical Group has been proposed, to convene government authorities and member agencies working in Azerbaijan, summarize basic principles of good programming for MHPSS and build consensus among different actors in the field, providing a coherent framework to organizations implementing MHPSS activities in their different sectors. The main tasks of the MHPSS Technical Working Group Coordinator in Baku, Azerbaijan will be to:• Establish the MHPSS Technical Group as a forum for sharing of information and activities of national and international entities providing MHPSS services.• Coordinate the MHPSS Technical Group, support the activities of the MHPSS actors, work closely with ministries at national and provincial levels, academia, NGOs, professional organizations and Donor Community• Contribute to the design of and deliver capacity building actions such as training of trainers, specialized training and awareness raising initiatives (orientation seminars, mini-trainings, briefings, project reviews) for MHPSS Technical Group members and for the Government of Azerbaijan.• Support the planning, development and monitoring of the implementation, and capacity building activities at national/subnational level to respond to the mental health and psychosocial needs of frontline responders and essential workers.The MHPSS TG will use the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) Guidelines for Mental Health and Psychosocial Support in Emergencies and other MHPSS related documents developed by WHO and other agencies as key policy documents for programming and interventions addressing all levels of the MHPSS needs.

title.narrative: Towards a new port development strategy for Indonesia

description.narrative: The Indonesian Ministry of Transport (MoT) and Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs (Menko Maritim) are in an immediate need for support to overcome the challenges they face in the port sector. Indonesian counterparts of the Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management need to rethink various aspects of port development strategies in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis. The organization of a series of webinars, followed by the jointly development strategy document, would greatly support the Indonesian challenges

title.narrative: Safe Trade Emergency Program Mozambique

description.narrative: Safe Trade Emergency Program for Mozambique (STEPMOZ) mitigates the short-term COVID-19 crisis by making trade safer at two key border points, between Mozambique and Malawi, along the Beira Corridor. This responds to demand from the Government of Mozambique and private sector partners to keep the road borders and corridors open.

receiver-org.narrative: Parkeer (hier mogen alle foutieve aanvragen aan gekoppeld)

title.narrative: Support to financial monitoring system, Pakistan

description.narrative: The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) is an intergovernmental organization to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism. The objectives of FATF are to set standards and promote effective implementation of legal, regulatory and operational measures to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism, to protect the integrity of the international financial system.Pakistan is still on the grey-list of the FATF also after the latest assessment in October 2020. a new assessment will take place to judge whether the country should be blacklisted. This situation harms the business climate of the country and has a negative impact on the financial crisis Pakistan is currently in. Therefore, this project aims to support the FMU (directly) and the Ministry of Commerce of Pakistan (indirectly) and therewith the financial sector via knowledge exchange with the Dutch Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU-NL), in order to comply with the criteria set by the FATF and be able to move to the white list. FIU-NL has valuable expertise that can assist FMU Pakistan in improving its way of working and thereby supporting Pakistan in reforming its financial system and implementing FATF criteria and recommendations. Their knowledge will be shared via remote assistance to FMU and a study visit of FMU and TAMLIT to the FIU-NL in the Netherlands, if the COVID situation allows.

title.narrative: ILO Decent work textile VN MY

description.narrative: The ILO project, lasting two to three years (2021-2023), aims to support the Governments of Viet Nam and Myanmar in skills forecasting and skills development. It should prevent the textiles and clothing industries in Asia to revert to business as usual after the COVID-19 crisis. The society must build back better and invest in more resilient, inclusive and sustainable sectors and societies. In the textiles and clothing industries, which were already undergoing a rapid and profound digital and robotics transformation, skills development and forecasting are key to helping employers and workers navigate an uncertain future and to advancing decent and sustainable work.This funding concerns an ILO project with a total project budget of 650,000 US Dollar, with contribution of:• RVO: 400,000 Euro (480,000 US Dollar);• ILO/Japan Fund for Building Social Safety Nets in Asia and the Pacific: 100,000 US Dollar, and • National governments: 70,000 US Dollar in kind.

title.narrative: Online Poultry Seminar Democratic Republic Congo

description.narrative: The study ‘Increasing self-sufficiency in poultry meat and egg production in Kinshasa’ was carried out by WUR in 2018 and because of the political situation in DRC and COVID not much follow up could be given in 2019 and 2020. In Q1 of 2021 an online event on the study will be organized with local stakeholders as well as Dutch participants.The goal is a wider dissemination of the results and conclusions of the study, creating a platform for stakeholders of the poultry industry in the DRC to discuss the possibilities to further develop the sector, identifying opportunities for the private sector as well as recommendations for the public sector in order to support the development of the poultry sector and by connecting Congolese actors to the expertise of the Dutch poultry sector.

title.narrative: Rural connectivity for the young: support to Hosts for Peace project in Nariño and Putumayo, Colombia

description.narrative: The implementation of the Peace Agreement with FARC in Colombia is supported by the Netherlands through political and financial commitment via the European Union Trust Fund for Peace (EUTF). The multiannual plan of the Embassy supports the implementation of the Comprehensive Rural Reform to strengthen local economies (training, agricultural production chains and access to markets) of communities affected in the internal conflict in Colombia. The project complements the ongoing Host for Peace project that is being implemented by ICCO cooperation with support of the EUTF to offer vocational training and support business initiatives in the Putumayo and Nariño regions; two of the most affected regions of the internal conflict in Colombia.. The project enables rural connectivity and ensures the continuity and finalization of the training in entrepreneurship (gastronomy and tourism) of 262 rural young Afro-Colombian women through an inclusive business model during the COVID-19 pandemic crisis that doesn’t allow presential training due to the lock down measures. The project leads to the further development of micro and small businesses by increasing the affordable offer of internet in remote areas of these regions.

receiver-org.narrative: Parkeer (hier mogen alle foutieve aanvragen aan gekoppeld)

title.narrative: Chamber of Commerce Training of Trainers

description.narrative: The Federation of Palestinian Chambers of Commerce, Industry and Agriculture (FPCCIA) based in Ramallah is piloting the founding of an ‘ICU unit’ to help MSMEs which are negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The ICU unit will provide MSMEs with technical assistance. For the pilot, 20 MSMEs have been selected and the major areas of improvement have been identified in a study. Through RVO’s support, 18 trainers (one from each Palestinian Chamber of Commerce, which are members of FPCCIA) will be trained on four topics of improvement, so that they can support the MSMEs as an ICU unit (training of trainers). The expert giving the training of trainers will also coach the selected 20 MSMEs in the pilot phase.

title.narrative: Camote and other Roots-Tubers Value Chain Improvement

description.narrative: The main problem to be solved is the inability of producers and anchor companies to comply with the requirements of non-tariff barriers to food safety and other aspects derived from COVID 19 that are being included in the quality certification standards and sustainable seals. None of the anchor companies have quality or safety certifications. The goal is to build the capacity of the personnel of the companies with whom the improvement plans will be implemented, in order to ensure that when the certifying body carries out the inspection, they will pass the examination and obtain certification.By executing the improvement plans for the to be selected collection and processing plants with the participation of the personnel in charge of collection, processing, certification and field technicians, the companies will be prepared to pass the certification body's examination and obtain GMP, FSMA and Global Gap certification, which will enable them to negotiate contracts and better prices with European buyers of fresh fruit.In addition, the technical and certification personnel directly in contact with the producers will be trained to transmit knowledge on the application of the Global GAP standard, which will also have an impact on producers and other crops with export potential, such as pitahaya, soursop and lemon.The project will be developed in the northern part of Nicaragua, North Caribbean Coast, municipalities of El Rama, the department of Leon (municipality of Leon), the department of Masaya (municipality of Tisma and Masaya) and the department of Granada (municipality of Granada).

title.narrative: Scoping study healthcare Philippines

description.narrative: In 2019 the President of the Philippines signed the Universal Healthcare Act into law, kicking off what is supposed to be an ambitious overhaul of the Philippine healthcare system. In 2020 the COVID-19 pandemic hit the Philippines, exposing some of the shortcomings of the Philippine healthcare system in software, hardware and orgware. The starting point for this project is the current situation: how does the health care sector look like, who are the stakeholders, and what venues are there for potential cooperation between the Netherlands and the Philippines in the healthcare sector?This project will result in an analytical report on the sector, a road map with proposed follow-up actions for the embassy and two webinars for Dutch and Philippines stakeholders on the results of the study. This study should serve as the starting point for further development of local private healthcare parties with the ultimate goal of strengthening the Philippines healthcare sector.

title.narrative: Consumer behaviour & food safety poultry in Myanmar

description.narrative: This project is about the increase and the acceptance and food safety awareness and improve the reputation of professionally slaughtered and processed poultry meat among Myanmar consumers.In 2020, the first modern poultry slaughterhouse of Myanmar, with a capacity of 1,000 birds per hour, has been opened at the premises of Wai Yang Aung in Yangon. Allowing to meet the highest international standards in terms of hygiene, food safety, working conditions and animal welfare. However, Myanmar consumers are hard to convince to buy cooled or frozen poultry meat slaughtered at professional slaughterhouses instead of whole birds to be slaughtered at home or wet markets. Thus, the arrival of modern slaughterhouses does not automatically imply that consumers will shift towards buying these poultry products.Therefore, the poultry meat processors, retail chains and public stakeholders will be advised on the most promising marketing campaign approach, including an implementation roadmap, to boost the reputation of and the demand for hygienically slaughtered, processed, stored and transported poultry meat.The current COVID-19 pandemic and growing global attention for food safety offer a good momentum to initiate a shift in consumer behaviour.

Nexus Project Peru: NL-PE expert support for implementation of Santa Eulalia scoping mission water, energy and food security (WEF)

description.narrative: Peru, together with the Netherlands, are part of the UN High Level Panel on Water (HLWP) and both are convening countries of the Global Commission on Adaptation. The Water Energy and Food Security (WEF) nexus approach fit in the overall national and international policy ambitions of both countries to ensure efficient use of natural resources and solve climate change challenges.The project complements and facilitates the implementation of the scoping mission of the project “WEF Nexus in the Santa Eulalia river basin in Lima, Peru. This mission is implemented by Deltares (water), TNO (energy) and Wageningen University (food) in a digital format due to the travel restrictions imposed by the COVID 19 pandemic. The purpose of the scoping mission is to better understand the current situation in the Santa Eulalia river basin, to consult with the key stakeholders and to identify the current and future problems related to the water, agriculture and energy sectors. This to be able to formulate more precisely the objectives, scope and deliverables of the PSD WEF nexus study for Santa Eulalia river basin planned for 2021. The WEF project will help reduce and/or avoid potential trade-offs over the use of increasingly limited water (surface water and groundwater), energy, land and food resources and will promote a better management of these resources at the local, regional and national level.This project provides local and Dutch technical and operational support to the Netherlands embassy in Lima for a successful implementation of the digital scoping missions.

title.narrative: Coastal erosion in Colombia – opportunities for collaboration related to the Masterplan Coastal Erosion (PMEC)

description.narrative: As a result of the cooperation between the governments of Colombia and The Netherlands, the Coastal Erosion Masterplan (Plan Maestro de Erosión Costera - PMEC) was drafted in the year 2017. The plan was subsequently presented to the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development (MADS) for revision by the Technical Committee for the PMEC.The objective of PMEC is to develop a long-term, comprehensive, sustainable national vision and strategy with adequate technical, financial and institutional support, in order to prevent, mitigate and control erosion and its consequences on the coasts of Colombia. In this respect, the design principle of ‘Building with Nature’ plays a crucial role. As part of the Delta Cooperation between the Netherlands and Colombia, the implementation of the PMEC is defined as one of the prioritized activities for 2019/2020. In order to distinguish if, which, when and how further assistance from The Netherlands with respect to the implementation of PMEC is efficient, it is necessary to get a better view of the needs of different national, regional and local organizations in Colombia regarding coastal erosion. The measures that the national entities have taken so far as well as the projected activities regarding coastal erosion / PMEC.For these purposes, the Netherlands government, through a Colombian-Dutch consortium led by Arcadis, carried out two missions to contact various organizations related to coastal erosion in two possible sites of PMEC implementation (Sucre and La Guajira departments), to which a third site was added (San Andres and Providencia). The outcomes and activities of the project were severely affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, which created difficulties in connecting with national entities.This project is conducted in cooperation with: JeSyCa SAS, Fundacion Herencia Ambiental Caribe, Colombian and Netherlands government.

title.narrative: Other - People reached

PRCS/L Health in Crisis Phase III

description.narrative:
Lebanon is being hit by crisis after crisis, with a state of emergency in place and the political freeze continuing. The nationwide economic collapse and the COVID-19 pandemic have a huge impact on the whole population and especially refugees. Due to the protracted crisis situation, PRCS/L has to respond to an increased demand on their life-saving services. Unfortunately trends in the humanitarian domain in Lebanon are giving a very worrisome prognosis for 2021 from a political, socio-economic, security, and public health perspective.
Due to the fact that PRCS/L does not have a formal legal status in Lebanon, PRCS/L cannot run income generation activities. In combination with the reduction of UNRWA funds and PRCS/L being a subcontractor of UNRWA, PRCS/L has suffered a huge dent in the availability of funds to sustain their ambulance and outreach services and to keep their hospitals running.
PRCS/L Health in Crisis Phase III
Palestinian Red Crescent Society Lebanon Branch and Netherlands Red Cross

This project aims to continue support to PRCS/L’s core activities building on NLRC’s support over the past years, as well as complement that of other RC/RC Movement and external partners, in providing medicine, medical supplies for patients and to 5 PRCS/L hospitals that all support PRCS/L’s overall mandate and mission. The operational strategy of the project is to improve the health of the most vulnerable Palestinian refugees, Syrians, Lebanese and other vulnerable communities in Lebanon by strengthening the health emergency response capacity of PRCS/L.

3FM Serious Request 2017: Restoring Family Links

description.narrative:
The programme, 3FM SR 2017 RFL, aims to restore the contact between family members that have lost track of each other due to armed conflict, natural disasters or migration, in particular vulnerable children, will trace lost children and family members, and reunifies the family members when possible. This project focusses on RFL capacity building for migrants.

title.narrative: Access to Health IV

description.narrative:
Almost the whole population of the Gaza Strip, two million people, are negatively affected by ongoing deficits and needs in the WASH sector. This includes 983.623 women and 991.428 children, who are exposed to public health risks associated to poor water quality (97% of water from Gaza’s sole aquifer is unfit for human consumption), poor wastewater collection and treatment, lack of stormwater infrastructure and lack of proper hygiene practices. This is compounded by the lack of electricity. Today Gaza’s residents receive eight hours of electricity at a time, followed by an eight-hour power cut. As a direct consequence of the shortage in electricity, the operational capacity to run Gaza’s public services dropped dramatically at the municipal level, especially across crucial sectors, such as water and sanitation.
Water and sanitation infrastructure in health facilities has deteriorated to the point that clinics have frequently had to shut down. The added pressure on the healthcare system from the spread of COVID-19 heightens healthcare facilities’ need for continuous and safe water, sanitation and hygiene materials. Without proper access to water, sanitation and hygiene, the ability of health care workers to carry out proper infection prevention and control measures, and provide even basic, routine services, is greatly compromised.
Palestinian Red Crescent Society and Netherlands Red Cross Society

The operational strategy is articulated through the following outcomes: Outcome 1: Improved access to safe water through new construction or rehabilitation of the current water infrastructure within PRCS Health Care Facilities (HCFs). Outcome 2: Access to sanitation infrastructure is provided for patients and staff in PRCS HCFs, including waste water networks and stormwater drainage systems. Outcome 3: Solid waste infrastructure in PRCS HCFs is rehabilitated and upgraded, including collection, treatment and disposal. Outcome 4: PRCS Health Care Facilities have increased capacities to manage their WASH infrastructure, including WASH in Emergency preparedness and response. Outcome 5: PRCS health staff is enabled to implement infection prevention and control (IPC) measures and facilities are provided with essential IPC supplies and equipment. Outcome 6: Solar panels are installed to ensure continuous renewable energy supply in Al-Quds Hospital.

The project will contribute to PRCS’s and NLRC’s strategy by enhancing the provision of quality basic WASH services in health care institutions. This project will work on mitigating threats and improving preparedness for potential outbreaks. The project envisages rehabilitation of the WASH facilities and instalment of solar panels in the four primary health care clinics (PHCC) and two hospitals of PRCS in Gaza. The project will improve the access and sustainability of quality WASH and Health services for an average of 300.000 people served annually by the four PHCC and two hospitals.

PRCS additional response COVID-19

description.narrative: Contribute to saving lives and mitigating against the impact of COVID-19; contribute to saving lives and reduce the impact of the pandemic by addressing the gaps in the national health system

From the beginning of February 2021, Palestine has seen a rapid escalation of COVID-19 cases, which the authorities have labeled as the start of the third wave of infection. The public hospitals are struggling to manage the influx of severe patients in need of intensive care. While PRCS has already started initiatives to support the health authorities to expand homebased care under which patients will be provided with oxygen concentrators and pulse oxymeters if needed, thus helping the authorities addresses the gaps. PRCS /Al-Bireh branch and Al-Bireh Municipality, in consultation with PRCS HQ, have agreed to establish a COVID-19 Field Hospital in an urban setting to support the MOH in managing the overflow of COVID-19 inpatients from MOH facilities. The Field Hospital will be located in a municipality-owned, multipurpose event center in the city of Al-Bireh, in Ramallah and Al Bireh Governorate. It will start rendering services initially with 54 beds, including four for ICU1 and have ten nurses and six doctors as well as support staff (cleaners, clerks, etc.).
Palestinian Red Crescent Society and Netherlands Red Cross Society

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Cool Schools Lebanon

description.narrative: Lebanese schools' capacity is overstretched, as they are providing education to both local population and refugees. Often in two shifts per day. Drop-out rates are at risk of rising, due to insufficient water and sanitation in the schools to provide a clean and safe environment for girls and boys. This project aim is to strengthen the community’s resilience and prevent waterborne diseases.
Lebanon - areas that host Syrian refugees.
Netherlands Red Cross and Lebanese Red Cross

Support to Lebanese schools that host both children of Syrian refugee population and host communities. The project supports the water and sanitation structures in the schools, as well as promotion of hygiene practices among the pupils. With the help of the WASH in Schools II project, the LRC WASH team can thus promote safer hygiene practices, which is especially important in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The project will enable and ensure healthy and dignified educational conditions for students in Lebanese public schools whether they are Syrian refugees or from vulnerable Lebanese families through strengthened hygienic behaviors, provision of safe water, improved sanitary conditions, and environmentally sustainable interventions. The Lebanese Red Cross provides 'hardware' support: repairing water tanks, toilets, assessing privacy and safety levels. In addition, 'software' activities: hygiene promotion and installation of sanitation committees composed of school children.

description.narrative: Afghanistan has been in a state of protracted conflict for over 40 years compounding a high level of continued vulnerability across Afghan social fabric. According to the Fragile State Index, Afghanistan is in a state of high alert as ninth most fragile country in the world. In a population of estimated more than 37 million people, more than a third of the population is now in humanitarian need due to conflict, disaster and COVID-19
Contribution to the Afghanistan Country Operational Plans of 2021 and 2022. NLRC funding source: Block Grant 2018-2021 - Chronic Crises

UNICEF ECHO HIP 2020

description.narrative: Au total, la population des communes de Les Anglais, Chardonnières et Tiburon qui bénéficiera des activités du projet sera les élèves de l’école-abri qui sera réhabilité, les personnes utilisant le point d’eau, les 75 volontaires qui seront formés pour appuyer la population en période d’urgence et la population qui sera hébergée dans l’abri en cas d’aléa.
Département du Sud. Communes de Chardonnières, Les Anglais, Tiburon

La CRNL travail en Haïti en étroite coordination avec la CR Haitienne (CRH) comme institution auxiliaire de l’état pour la préparation et la réponse aux urgences (voir coordination avec la DPC), et la Fédération International de la CR (FICR) ainsi que les autres Sociétés Nationales Participantes (SNP) présentes dans le pays. Dans le cadre de cet accord la CRNL s’engage à faciliter la coordination de l’UNICEF avec la CRH, afin d’organiser des activités de préparation et réponse aux urgences avec une couverture dans le Grand-Sud, en cas de nécessitée (ces dernières activités ne sont pas incluses dans le présent projet, mais pourront faire partie d’un accord de partenariat séparé).

L’expérience a démontré qu’Haïti est très vulnérable aux épidémies, en témoigne l’épidémie de choléra au cours de laquelle plus de 820 000 cas suspects ont été recensés entre 2010 et 2019 et qui a fait plus de 10 000 morts selon le MSPP. Cette pandémie de Covid-19 s’inscrit donc dans un contexte sanitaire déjà très précaire avec des conséquences potentiellement dramatiques pour la population haïtienne, particulièrement les ménages les plus vulnérables qui ont vu leur situation socio-économique et sanitaire se dégrader continuellement depuis le début de l’année 2018. Au niveau national, il n’y a que 26 sites de prise en charge de Covid-19 soit 1 011 lits pour recevoir les patients, pour une population de 11 millions d’habitants.
Projet d’amélioration des capacités de préparation et de réponse aux urgences des acteurs locaux et de la résilience des communautés face aux crises climatiques, sociales et épidémiologiques.

title.narrative: Covid-19 Response CAR

description.narrative: A project that aims to address the spread of COVID-19 in CAR through Health and WaSH measures.

Contribute to the implementation of the national response plan to COVID-19 disease in the Central African Republic i.e. to reduce the risk of further spread of COVID-19 through risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) and health and hygiene promotion activities at epicentres of infection as prioritized by the Ministry of Health. This intervention will be undertaken primarily to cover 18 localities for the time being and for a period of 6 months, depending on the development of the pandemic in the country and the MoH priorities.

This operation will focus on RCCE through social mobilization, and promotion of positive health and hygiene practices through sensitisation campaigns, handwashing campaigns, surveillance or early referral activities, SGBV and psychosocial support, especially for DBM teams, health workers as well as the community. The Movement Coordination will support the CRCA to ensure effective participation of communities by providing information needs on COVID-19, setting up feedback mechanism as guided by the IFRC CEA standards and Core Humanitarian Standards (CHS). The approach for the risk communication will be done through the most effective and appropriate channels of communication with communities.

COVID-19 Preparedness and Response in Kassala and West Darfur, Sudan

description.narrative: Supported activities include health and hygiene promotion, community surveillance, communication and community engagement and small scale wash hardware.
The overall targeted beneficiaries for both states is 591,757.

The world is facing an unprecedented situation with the onset of the COVID-19 epidemic. In the global south, which already has poor public health outcomes, the potential impact on communities is catastrophic. People in Sudan have limited knowledge of COVID-19 and misconceptions and false information are being shared widely, including through social media. Severe restrictions, such as a full lockdown of movement outside of the home is challenging in Sudan as the economy is reliant on daily workers. Although placing extensive limitation of movement may assist to prevent the spread of COVID-19, it will likely mean food insecurity for a large proportion of the population and other high risk scenarios and unhealthy coping mechanisms. Preparing and responding to COVID-19 epidemic is further complicated in Sudan due to a declining economic and unstable political situation in-country, including ongoing protests, a new government, lack of basic commodities such as fuel and bread and increasing inflation.

This action will support Sudanese Red Crescent Society (SRCS) to implement their preparedness and response plan for COVID-19 in Kassala and West Darfur Branches, Sudan. The overall goal of SRCS is to contribute to the response to the COVID 19 outbreak by preventing human-to-human transmission of the virus caring for those affected in Sudan.

COVID-19 Response and Preparedness South Sudan

description.narrative: Activities included in this response focus on trainings of volunteers on WaSH and Health, hygiene promotion, improving access to safe water and public health awareness raising.

South Sudan can expect a massive impact within a matter of weeks if no effective measures are taken early in the COVID-19 outbreak, unless effective suppression and control measures are enacted in all areas with active outbreaks. The risk of further COVID-19 importation to South Sudan has been assessed to be high.
The overall targeted beneficiaries for this intervention is 85,000.

This intervention will support South Sudanese Red Cross (SSRC) to contribute to prevention of COVID-19 transmission in South Sudan’s main hub, Juba. The overall goal of SSRC is to contribute to the prevention and control of COVID-19 community transmission through increased knowledge among health care workers and Red Cross volunteers; and improved preventive COVID-19 hygiene behavior by the vulnerable population.
